intro: Echinopsis puquiensis, commonly known as the Puquiensis cactus, is a species of cactus native to the arid regions of South America, particularly in Argentina and Chile. It is characterized by its short, cylindrical stems that are often covered in white, woolly spines. The plant produces vibrant yellow or orange flowers during the warmer months, which are typically short-lived but highly attractive to pollinators. Echinopsis puquiensis is well adapted to harsh desert conditions, storing water in its thick, fleshy stems. Its unique appearance and ecological role make it an important species in its native habitat.
